items.abstract: <jats:p>Investigations were carried-out on turnip root celery (<i>Apium graveolens</i> L. var. <i>rapaceum</i> Gaud.). Aim of the study was to examine the biology of flowering and the degree of flower atractiveness, as well as the insect influence on their pollination. The research was conducted during 1979 and 1981 vegetation seasons. Observations were made near Lublin on the loessy brown soil. Seeds were the most abundant in IV and V umbel rows. The isolated flowers did not produce less fertile seeds than the non-isolated ones. Recorded pollen production ranged to 100 kg per ha. The <i>Syrphidae</i> which pollinated celery, fed on their pollen.</jats:p>
title: The biology of flowering and pollination in umbellate vegetables. Part III. (Apium graveolens L. var. rapaceum Gaud.)

items.abstract: <jats:p>The aim of the study was to examine not only the occurrence of bloom of parsley, but also the degree of attractiveness of the flowers as well as the influence of insects on their pollination. There search was carried out during the 1978 and 1979 vegetation seasons. Observations were carried out near Lublin, on loess brown soil. The flowers of isolated plants were washed in order to determined the sugar content in nectar with a refractometer. The number of secreting stomata on the epidermis of nectary was on the average 575 per 1 mm<sup>2</sup>. The sugar weight in parsley equals 0.2 mg and the honey yield was 62.4 kg in 1978 and 160 kg in 1979 per ha. The yield of the nectar was mainly influenced by the 3rd row of urnbells. Isolation of flowers from pollinators caused a decrease of seed yield from 7% to 55% in 1978 and 21% to 38% in 1979. The presence of entomofauna on the flowers should be taken into consideration cohen the forecasting the seed yield in horticultural production of parsley.</jats:p>
title: The biology of flowering and pollination in umbellate vegetables. Part II. Petroselinum sativum Hoffm.

items.abstract: <jats:p>The biology of blooming of garden dill and the influence of insect pollination on seed seetting was investigated. The experiment was carried out near Lublin, on the loessy soils within two different habitats in the season 1977-78. In order to determine the sugar weight of nectar isolated flowers were washed out, then the water enclosed in the nectar was vaporized and the remaining sugars underwent repeated dissolution and determined quantitatively with refractometer. The pollen yield was determined with the ether-weight method. The number of the secreting stomata on the epidermis of the nectary was on the average 950 per 1 mm<sup>2</sup>. The sugar weight of 0.4 mg and pollen weight of 0.63 mg from 10 flowers informed of the attractiveness ofthe garden dill for the pollinating insects. The estimated honey yield of garden dill was 27.8 kg ha<sup>-1</sup> and pollen yield was 18.7 kg ha<sup>-1</sup>. The isolation of the flowers from the pollinators brought about the decrease of the seed yield of 30% in 1977 and of 43% in 1978. The presence of the entomofauna on the flowers must be taken into consideration when forecasting the seed yield in the horticultural production of the garden dill.</jats:p>
title: Biology of the bloom and pollination of the umbelliferous vegetables. Part I: Garden dill (Anethum graveolens L.)
